awd_titl_txt: Transient Intermediates of Electron and Proton Transfer
awd_abstract_narration:
In this project funded by the Chemical Structure, Dynamic & Mechanism B Program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Frantisek Turecek of the Department of Chemistry at University of Washington, Seattle, is developing new methods of investigating transient intermediates of chemical reactions involving biologically relevant compounds such as proteins and DNA.  Transient intermediates such as ions or chemical radicals occur when proteins and DNA are damaged.  Understanding of the chemical processes, their mechanisms, and nature of reactive intermediates associated with ionization and chemical radical damage to proteins and DNA helps to develop improved means for DNA and protein protection and repair.  The project lies at the interface of organic, physical, and bioanalytical chemistry, and has a proven record of providing all-round education to scientists at all levels. This research group welcomes students currently or historically underrepresented in science and is well-positioned to provide the highest level of education and training.  In addition, the group is active both nation-wide and internationally in fostering collaborations with other research groups and institutes. 

The research consists of three main aims. In Aim 1, the group combines two techniques, gas-phase electron transfer and UV photodissociation action spectroscopy, to achieve insight into the electronic structure of transient radical intermediates of biological reactions of proteins and nucleic acids. Studying these biomolecules with model systems of limited size, such as peptides and DNA fragments, makes them amenable to computational analysis. Aim 2 concerns the structure and dynamics of non-covalent biomolecular complexes. The approach, which combines experimental mass spectrometry studies with Born-Oppenheimer molecular dynamics calculations, is likely to produce valuable information on the character and magnitude of non-covalent bonding in biomolecular complexes. Aim 3 utilizes a new synthetic coupling reaction for solid-phase peptide derivatization and improves mass-spectrometric analysis with the aim of achieving de novo sequencing of unknown peptides.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
This research project addressed the formation, nature, and structure of ionized radicals (cation-radicals) that play a role in destructive processes of DNA and protein radiation damage. Cation radicals are highly reactive and thus appear as short-lived, transient, intermediates of chemical reactions that are triggered by ionization events caused by UV photon or elementary particle impacts. Transient intermediates are extremely difficult to study because of their short lifetime. To address these issues and avoid adverse side reactions, we have developed new experimental methods aimed at generating cation radicals related to DNA and protein components as isolated species in the rarefied gas phase, and elucidating their structure by laser spectroscopy in combination  with mass spectrometry.  We complemented our experimental studies with extensive quantum chemistry calculations to help us interpret the spectra and provide data on energy and reaction kinetics. These studies have resulted in the characterization of several cation radicals of DNA nucleobases and nucleotides for which we have been able to obtain spectra in the ultraviolet and visible region. The major intellectual merit of these studies has been the discovery of hitherto unknown noncanonical forms of DNA nucleobase cation radicals that were found to be thermodynamically more stable than the usual textbook structures. According to our calculations, the new noncanonical DNA nucleobase cation radicals, as well as those of related nucleosides, are much less amenable to reduction by electron attachment compared to the classical cation radicals. This may change the standing paradigm of  DNA ionization and damage propagation in the ions. The new findings may have broader impacts in chemistry and biology, in particular as related to DNA and proteins.

The reported research project has been carried out by several PhD graduate students that obtained wide-ranging training in experimental and computational chemistry. PhD graduates who had worked on this project have since been active both as scientists in the biopharmaceutical industry and at information technology companies.  Thus, the combination of  experimental and computational scientific training provided by this research project has had a broad impact of creating superbly qualified work force for cutting-edge U.S. industries.         


Last Modified: 09/23/2021
Modified by: Frantisek Turecek

Image
  • A DNA cation-radical transient intermediate is formed by electron capture in charged DNA and probed by laser photodissociation. The obtained UV-Vis spectrum, after computational interpretation, provides the cation radical structure.
    Frantisek Turecek
    Public Domain
    Frantisek Turecek
    DNA highlights
